nodes.bodyText: notAny
Fixed in 6a01e16
.equals?

Removed this anonymous class. Now using ReplaceUnknownOperandTypeInference, where this specific == has been replaced with equals.
See 6a01e16
that's not ascii, that's unicode code point

What is the problem with it? Will it return incorrect values for some ASCII characters?
The behavior of this function is not well-defined for non-ASCII characters. The only common thing across databases is that it should return the value that could be converted back to the same character through CHR/NCHAR/etc function. This will be possible with Character.toChars() when it is time to implement CHR function.
Perhaps a simple cast should also work fine.
if at least one operand is null, it should return null

There is no such requirement in the standard. It is up to the vendor to decide how to treat NULL values here. E.g. PG and MySQL return NULL in this case, while Oracle and SQL Server treats NULL as an empty string.
Why do you think that returning NULL is better than treating it as an empty string?

From the standard:
<concatenation> ::= <character value expression> <concatenation operator> <character factor>
...
Let S1 and S2 be the result of the <character value expression> and <character factor>, respectively.
...
If either S1 or S2 is the null value, then the result of the <concatenation> is the null value.
Fixed in 2dab533
if escape was provided and its value is null, it should return null
Fixed in bf96a79
never used
Fixed
never used
Fixed
why title case and not upper case?

There are some very subtle differences for some characters, e.g. [1]. I think both variants are good enough.
[1] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47887244/whats-the-difference-between-character-touppercase-and-character-totitlecase/47887432#47887432
upper case letters should be lowercased if they are not starting a word
Fixed in e2c7927
if start was provided and its value is null, it should return null
Fixed in 37f0ac6
if length was provided and its value is null, it should return null
Fixed in 37f0ac6
Is it possible for substring to have 1 argument?
Yes, in this case it is a no-op.
Wrong. It is not supported. Fixed RexToExpression.

Maybe we should include the original exception in the message. The user won't see the cause, i wonder if it will even be in the member logs.
Also I couldn't find a test for this scenario.
"NPE on" -> "NPE in"

This is a defensive handler "just in case". We are going to make expressions more restrictive, not allowing any argument here except for strings, so exceptions will never happen. Meanwhile, this handler is added just for some unexpected situations that I cannot even imagine how to reproduce.
Let's assume that this handler will be removed soon during expressions polishing.

It might be better to catch the exc in ObjectConverter.asVarchar(), when it calls the toString. Then it would not be necessary to handle it specially here if I'm not mistaken.
To test it we can query an OBJECT value with broken toString method.
OBJECT Is restricted on the upper level at the moment. We cannot pass a custom object here at the moment.
Maybe we should name this StringFunctionUtils - everything else in this package uses "function", there's also MathFunctionUtils

nodes.bodyText: SUBSTRING(this, 1, 1) syntax is also valid, shouldn't we test it? I guess after calcite parsing it's the same for us...
Added such tests
This line is not covered by integration test. Actually I can't figure out how can you pass null operand2.
No longer relevant, since the function cannot have 1 argument
This can be >=
Fixed

I didn't get the comment. Could you please clarify the problem?
If this is about two branches with identical content (if (length == null) and if (adjustedStart + length > input.length())), then this is intentional to make code simpler to understand
The point was that we don't to special-case when adjustedStart == 0. input.substring(0) works just fine, it returns input. The same test for start == 0 is inside of String.substring.
I see. Formally, String.substring() still does additional checks, so I'd better avoid calling it as a micro-opt
We should capitalize not only after whitespace, but also after any non-letter. Oracle, Postgresql, do this, mysql and mssql don't have this function.
Fixed. Now the condition to trigger capitalization of the next character is if (!Character.isLetterOrDigit(c))
Why the + "" +?
Leftover. Removed.
Fixed.
- isn't a top-level special char, only inside of [] or {}.

Fixed in 939d0a0
Also added a test to check escaping all special characters.

We enable DOTALL mode for .*, but not for .. Why not for both?
If we'll do it for both, we can instead pass the DOTALL flag to Pattern.compile and save some parsing time.
Also we miss tests for matching newlines.
Fixed in a26fc69

Why don't we use the term "regex"?

escaping in Java -> escaping in regex
convertToJavaPattern -> convertToRegex
lastJavaPattern -> lastRegex

etc.
It is a matter of taste.

If pattern = "(_" and escape = "(", we'll produce the regex \_ - the non-special _ will be unnecessarily escaped. This happens when the escape character is one of the regex special characters.
While I couldn't find any case where this is an issue (in regex you can unnecessarily escape any character), seems weird to produce such output.
I am not quite sure I understand the problem. Does it lead to incorrect results in any case?
It only causes that _ or % can be unnecessarily escaped. But since regex allows escaping any non-alphanumerical characters, it's not really a problem.
Applied the suggested change.
We can create the state immediately in constructor and don't need this branching.
The function might have never been invoked. No need to create it beforehand.

The state is 3 fields that will be null. And the case when the function is never invoked is rare. That's much cheaper than checking for nullity for every item. It's also less code, so in this regard it's a micro-optimization.
But I admit it's also a matter of style, so I'm marking as resolved.
Removed unnecessary check.

It should not work at all. We currently use too relaxed behavior that should be restricted otherwise. We'd better not dedicate more time to tests that otherwise should not work at all. This behavior will be restricted very soon.
